official-title.#text:
To amend the Inspector General Act of 1978 to strengthen the independence of the Inspectors
			 General, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 6. Amendments to the Inspector General Act of

header.#text: Additional authority provisions for Inspectors General
Subpoena authority for Inspectors General To require testimony of certain persons

text.#text:
In addition to the authority otherwise provided by this Act and in accordance with the requirements
			 of this section, each Inspector General, in carrying out the provisions of
			 this Act, is authorized to require by subpoena the attendance and
			 testimony of certain witnesses, including a contractor with the Federal
			 Government and any former Federal employee (but not including any Federal
			 employee), necessary in the performance of the functions assigned by this
			 Act, which subpoena, in the case of contumacy or refusal to obey, shall be
			 enforceable by order of any appropriate United States district court.

Before the issuance of a subpoena described in subsection (a), an Inspector General shall submit a
			 request for approval to issue a subpoena by a majority of a panel (in this
			 section, referred to as the

Except as provided in subparagraph (B), the Subpoena Panel shall approve or deny a request for
			 approval to issue a subpoena not later than 10 days after the submission
			 of such request.

If the Subpoena Panel determines that additional information is necessary to approve or deny such
			 request, the Subpoena Panel shall request such information and shall
			 approve or deny such request not later than 20 days after the submission
			 of such request.

If a majority of the Subpoena Panel denies the approval of a subpoena, that subpoena may not be
			 issued.

			 subpoena.

by redesignating subparagraph (C) as subparagraph (E); and

shall complete the investigation not later than six months after the date on which the Integrity
			 Committee made such determination;
if the investigation cannot be completed within such six-month period, shall—
promptly notify the congressional committees listed in paragraph (8)(A)(iii); and

to the maximum extent practicable, complete the investigation not later than 3 months after the
			 expiration of the six-month period; and

if the investigation cannot be completed within such nine-month period, shall brief the
			 congressional committees listed in paragraph (8)(A)(iii) every thirty days
			 until the investigation is complete.

If a determination is made under paragraph (5) to initiate an investigation, the Integrity

If an investigation of an allegation of wrongdoing against an Inspector General or a staff member
			 of an Office of Inspector General described under paragraph (4)(C) is
			 initiated by a governmental entity other than the Integrity Committee, the
			 Integrity Committee may conduct any related investigation for which a
			 determination to initiate an investigation was made under paragraph (5)
			 concurrently with the other government entity.

term.#tail: means the Special Counsel appointed under

text.#text:
An allegation of wrongdoing against the Special Counsel or the Deputy Special Counsel may be
			 received, reviewed, and referred for investigation by the Integrity
			 Committee to the same extent and in the same manner as in the case of an
			 allegation against an Inspector General (or a member of the staff of an
			 Office of Inspector General), subject to the requirement that the Special
			 Counsel recuse himself or herself from the consideration of any allegation
			 brought under this paragraph.

text.#text:

header.#text: Report on vacancies in the offices of inspector general

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall conduct a study of prolonged vacancies in the Offices of Inspector
			 General, during which a temporary appointee has served as the head of the
			 office that includes—

text.#text: the number and duration of Inspector General vacancies;

an examination of the extent to which the number and duration of such vacancies has changed over
			 time;

an evaluation of the impact such vacancies have had on the ability of the relevant Office of the
			 Inspector General to effectively carry out statutory requirements; and
recommendations to minimize the duration of such vacancies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall present a briefing on the findings of the study described in
			 subsection (a) to the

			 House of Representatives

header.#text: Report on issues involving multiple offices of inspector general

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall conduct an analysis of
			 critical issues that involve the jurisdiction of more than one individual
			 Federal agency or entity to identify—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency

text.#text:
each such issue that could be better addressed through greater coordination among, and cooperation
			 between, individual Offices of Inspector General;

the best practices that can be employed by the Offices of Inspector General to increase
			 coordination and cooperation on each issue identified; and

any recommended statutory changes that would facilitate coordination and cooperation among Offices
			 of Inspector General on critical issues.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall submit a report on the findings
			 of the analysis described in subsection (a) to the
